newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: CIS leaders vow to rebuff any Afghan border threat.
newsitem.headline: CIS leaders vow to rebuff any Afghan border threat.

text.p: The Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) has vowed to defend areas bordering on Afghanistan if fighting there spills over but leaders agreed at a summit meeting not to interfere in the conflict.

Five leaders of former Soviet republics, alarmed by the rise to power in Kabul of a radical Islamic militia, ended their summit on Friday with an appeal to the rival groups to hold talks and for the United Nations to discuss the situation.
"We call upon all warring parties to stop hostilities and resume peace negotiations," Kazakhstan's President Nursultan Nazarbayev said at a joint news conference.
He also accused the Taleban militia of committing human rights violations after the seizure of the capital Kabul last week, referring to the execution of some of the Taleban's political opponents.
"We denounce the executions and violations of human rights committed in Afghanistan," Nazarbayev said.
The Taleban's victims included former Moscow-backed Afghan president Najibullah, a communist installed as Afghan leader in 1987 during the 10-year Soviet occupation of the country.
The Almaty summit was attended by the presidents of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, as well as by Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin.
It was called to discuss possible steps if the Taleban advanced north to the southern borders of the CIS, a loose 12-member grouping formed as the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991.

Nazarbayev said participants at the summit would take "adequate measures" to defend themselves if the conflict spilled over from Afghanistan. But he and other participants made clear that no practical steps would be taken unless this happened.
"We are strongly against interference in Afghanistan's internal affairs," Nazarbayev said.
However, Uzbek President Islam Karimov said that Afghan warlord General Abdul Rashid Dostum was all that stood between the Taleban militia and the former Soviet republics.
Karmimov said that Dostum, who controls a strategic tunnel to northern Afghanistan, deserved stronger support from the neighbouring former Soviet states.
"If this tunnel is surrendered, they will have no obstacle on their way northwards and we don't know how far they may go," he said.
"If we do not want the war to escalate, if we want to force all parties to the negotiating table, we have to make sure that Dostum keeps the tunnel under his control."
There was no indication that the other leaders at the summit shared Karimov's views. Uzbekistan is one of three former Soviet Central Asian republics that border on Afghanistan.
Nazarbayev said he, Chernomyrdin, Tajik President Imomali Rakhmonov, Uzbekistan's Karimov and Kyrgyzstan President Askar Akayev wanted the U.N. Security Council to meet on Afghanistan.
He also said the five countries would start supplying northern Afghanistan with humanitarian aid to help the war-stricken civilian population.
Chernomyrdin said he thought that the future stand of the CIS states would largely depend on further steps by other countries which have an impact on the situation in Afghanistan.
"We are watching attentively what other countries are doing, including the United States and Pakistan," he said. "This, of course, will influence our position."
